p.s: Summary description of Actinosporangium vitaminophilum sp. nov.
Actinosporangium vitaminophilum (vi. ta. mi. no'phi. lum. L. n. vita life; M.L. n. aminum amine, hence vitamin; Gr. adj. philon loving; M.L. adj. vitaminophilum vitamin-loving.)
Pseudosporangia are 3 to 30 μm in diameter, spherical to oval, and sometimes irregular and are formed on aerial mycelium; there is no definite sporangial wall.
Spores are elliptical, 0.5 to 0.6 μm in diameter, and nonmotile, with smooth surfaces.
Aerial mycelium white and 0.7 to 0.8 μm in diameter.
The morphology described above is observed only on calcium malate agar supplemented with vitamin B12.
Poor growth on chemically defined media and moderate growth on organic media.
Growth on all media is pale tan or pale grayish yellow.
No distinct diffusible pigment is produced.
Utilizes D-glucose, D-xylose, L-rhamnose, and glycerol for growth, but not L-arabinose, D-fructose, D-mannitol, i-inositol, sucrose, or raffinose.
Cell wall type I; aerobic; mesophilic.
Produces antibiotics of the pyrrolomycin complex.
